Well, it's hard to say. The MBP can sometimes have shared GPU memory or some of them can be occupied with some other process (like X rendering). I'm using a Linux PC with no UI at all with a GTX 970 (4 GB of VRAM) and I could train with a batch size of 32. But I noticed that if there is not enough memory when I set the batch size to 32 it is put back to 16 before training by the system (I wouldn't call it bug, since otherwise would probably crash). What I would suggest you as alternative is to use CPU to make initial tests (with a iteration limit of ~200) to see if the loss lowers down in these iterations (with 200 iterations should already low enough to see that is training well), then I would move everything to an (example) Amazon GPU service and train everything there without setting any iteration limits (Turi Create has already a very good algorithm to guess the correct amount of iterations based on the input you have).

When I set the batch size to 32 (with GPU) in my script, the loss decreases with the number of iterations. I set it to 2000 and it worked fine (loss continue to decrease) for all iterations. The message showed the batch size is set to 16 still. I will probably run it w/o setting an iteration number so that the app can pick the right number. If I do not set the batch size, the loss becomes â€˜NaNâ€™. Since I am suspecting that the message displayed may not be reflecting the actual batch size, I cannot say what the default batch size is.
When using CPU, it automatically sets the batch size to 32 and the message shows the correct batch size. If I change the batch size to 16, it shows batch size is set to 16. Essentially, the batch size displayed is the same as what is set in my python script.
